Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Establishing Trustworthy-Citizen-Created Data for Disaster Response and Humanitarian Action

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Often referred to as microblogging, the practice of average citizens reporting on activities "on-the-ground" during a disaster is increasingly common. The contents of these message are potentially valuable to responder organizations and victims, but their volume makes it difficult to separate valuable messages from the stream. This project will examine microblogged messages sent during disasters to determine what aspects of the messages (individually and collectively) indicate that they are relevant, verifiable and actionable. Factors to be considered include the content of the messages, the identity of the sender and the overall pattern and spread of messages. The identified factors will then be used to instruct crowdsourced workers who will label messages to create a large corpus of labelled messages.

The project is important because microblogging data are seen as increasingly important: they are ubiquitous, rapid and accessible, and they are believed to empower average citizens to become more situationally aware during disasters and to coordinate to help themselves. The result of the project, if it is successful, will be evidence that it is possible to identify relevant, verifiable and actionable messages from a stream of microblogged messages and identification of the evidentiary factors. A further outcome will be a disaster-related, labeled dataset of messages, which will be useful to researchers, e.g., those seeking to automatically classify information within a microblogged data stream.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to construct gold-standard emergency-related datasets to be used to establish relevance and veracity of information during emergency events in the Twitter platform. This research was remarkably successful. The results include: (1) the development of gold standard, emergency-related, manually labeled datasets in which relevance and veracity regarding Hurricane Sandy and Boston bombings are verified; (2) the design of classification models that accurately identify tweets that convey emergency- related information and filter out those that are conversational in nature in order to narrow the data stream to relevant tweets; (3) sentiment analysis on Hurricane Sandy data to map fluctuations of emotions over time and space; and (4) the development of the concept of “good enough” data quality, focusing on identifying the threshold for actionable information by responding organizations.

This project resulted in several papers and conference presentations. Broader Impact: Two PhD students were supported through this grant. Three undergraduate and three high-school students (from the Texas Academy of Mathematics and Science program) were also involved in parts of the project. The Texas Academy of Mathematics and Science (TAMS) is a program for high-school Texas students interested in math and science, who are high achievers. Two of these TAMS high-school students presented components of this research and were awarded 3rd place in Computer Science at the Fort Worth Regional Science and Engineering Fair. As 3rd place winners, they were finalists at the Texas Science and Engineering Fair in San Antonio, TX. PI Caragea received a TAMS award for valuable contribution as a research mentor for high-school students. Components of this research have been introduced in course material taught by the PIs at UNT and PSU.
